title: Linear Algebra stuff

Articles about Linear Algebra and related topics.
Linear Algebra : Introduction

title: Introduction to linear algebra
text:
This notes are mainly based on : Linear Algebra and Optimization for Machine Learning


What is Linear Algebra ?
Linear Algebra is the study of linear operations on vector spaces.
What is a linear operation then …
Let \(V\) and \(W\) be vector spaces. A function \(f: V \rightarrow W\) is a linear map if for any two vectors \(\textbf{u}\) and \(\textbf{v}\) the mapping is operation preserving, that is, it satisfies these conditions:

Additivity : \(f(\textbf{u} + \textbf{v}) = f(\textbf{u}) + f(\textbf{v})\)
Homogeneity of scalar multiplication : \(f(\lambda \textbf{u}) = \lambda*f(\textbf{u})\)

For example :
Let’s say we have two vectors and a function \(f\): \[
\begin{aligned}
    \begin{split}
        \textbf{a} = [0, 1] \\
        \textbf{b} = [1 ,1] \\
    \end{split} \\
\end{aligned}
\]
And for any vector in two dimensions, we have this function : \(f(\textbf{v}) = f(a,b) = (3a,b)\)
This functions is operation preserving because, for example : \[
\begin{array}{3,1}
    f(a+b) = f([0,1] + [1,1]) = f([1,2]) = (3,2)\\
    \text{is equal to : }\\
    f(a) + f(b) = [0,1] + [3,1] = [3,2]
\end{array}
\]
It preserves the multiplication, for example, when \(\lambda = 2\): \[
\begin{array}{}
    f(\lambda * \textbf{b} ) = f(2*[1,1]) = f([2,2]) = [6,2]\\
    \text{Which is the same as :} \\
    \lambda * f(\textbf{b} ) = 2 * [3,1] = [6,2]
\end{array}
\]

title: Introduction to linear algebra
text:
What is Linear Algebra ?
Linear Algebra is the study of linear operations on vector spaces.
What is a linear operation then …
Let \(V\) and \(W\) be vector spaces. A function \(f: V \rightarrow W\) is a linear map if for any two vectors \(\textbf{u}\) and \(\textbf{v}\) the mapping is operation preserving, that is, it satisfies these conditions:

Additivity : \(f(\textbf{u} + \textbf{v}) = f(\textbf{u}) + f(\textbf{v})\)
Homogeneity of scalar multiplication : \(f(\lambda \textbf{u}) = \lambda*f(\textbf{u})\)

For example :
Let’s say we have two vectors and a function \(f\): \[
\begin{aligned}
    \begin{split}
        \textbf{a} = [0, 1] \\
        \textbf{b} = [1 ,1] \\
    \end{split} \\
\end{aligned}
\]
And for any vector in two dimensions, we have this function : \(f(\textbf{v}) = f(a,b) = (3a,b)\)
This functions is operation preserving because, for example : \[
\begin{array}{3,1}
    f(a+b) = f([0,1] + [1,1]) = f([1,2]) = (3,2)\\
    \text{is equal to : }\\
    f(a) + f(b) = [0,1] + [3,1] = [3,2]
\end{array}
\]
It preserves the multiplication, for example, when \(\lambda = 2\): \[
\begin{array}{}
    f(\lambda * \textbf{b} ) = f(2*[1,1]) = f([2,2]) = [6,2]\\
    \text{Which is the same as :} \\
    \lambda * f(\textbf{b} ) = 2 * [3,1] = [6,2]
\end{array}
\]
